author: By Vivian Giang
title: Behind the fight between Ben & Jerry’s and its owner, Unilever.
description: The ice cream maker is suing its corporate parent in an effort to stop sales in Israeli-occupied territories, thanks to an unusual deal that gives the founders control of the brand.
content: Ben & Jerry’s is suing its owner, the consumer products giant Unilever, in an unusual case that seeks to stop Unilever from selling the distribution rights of the ice cream brand in Israel to a local licensee.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matthew Cullen
title: Your Friday Briefing: Boris Johnson Plans to Resign
description: Also, Brittney Griner pleads guilty to Russian drug charges and Beijing has a new Covid strategy.
content: Standing alone at a lectern in front of 10 Downing Street, Boris Johnson announced that he would step down after three years as Britain’s prime minister, the result of a wholesale rebellion of his cabinet, a wave of government resignations and a devastating loss of party support prompted by recent scandals.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Hilarie M. Sheets
title: At the Laundromat Project, Artists Are Ambassadors of Joy and Activism
description: A nonprofit that has been supporting community-based artistic ventures inaugurates its new home in Brooklyn.
content: The Laundromat Project was founded two decades ago at a kitchen table on MacDonough Street in Bedford-Stuyvesant, Brooklyn, when Risë Wilson received her first grant money to make art experiences accessible to her neighbors — miles away and a world apart from gatekeeper institutions like the Metropolitan Museum of Art and the Museum of Modern Art.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Philip Galanes
title: How Do We Get Rid of Our Teenage Daughter’s Gun Safe?
description: A reader wonders what to do after her daughter responds to a breach of privacy by investing in a locker meant for weaponry, not diaries.
content: Our 15-year-old daughter is very headstrong. She’s never been in real trouble, but she bristles against rules and authority: curfews, homework, appropriate clothing — you name it! Recently, she exploded when her younger brothers discovered her journal in the family room. Now, she keeps it locked in a heavy black box she found at a secondhand store. The problem: The black box turns out to be a gun safe! (A friend of my husband told us.) We’re not worried that she has a gun; she helped organize a school rally to tighten our state’s gun laws. But she refuses to give up the safe, and we don’t want it in our house. Help!
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Beatrice Loayza
title: ‘Moon, 66 Questions’ Review: Daddy Issues
description: This elliptical drama by the Greek writer-director Jacqueline Lentzou rousingly summons the inner turmoil of a young woman who returns home to care for her ailing father.
content: The writer and director Jacqueline Lentzou’s “Moon, 66 Questions” takes cues from astrology, using Tarot cards to represent each new chapter of a story about a young woman, Artemis (Sofia Kokkali), who returns to Athens to care for her ailing father.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew Sullivan
title: The Outer Limits
description: In “The Shores of Bohemia,” John Taylor Williams explores 50 years in the iconoclastic summer colonies of Cape Cod.
content: There is something ineffable about the appeal of the outer reaches of Cape Cod to generations of writers, artists and architects. Maybe it’s simply that, as Thoreau observed, “a man may stand there and put all America behind him.” Maybe — and this was certainly true for the first part of the 20th century — it was the place’s remoteness and isolation, the sense that as the land reaches out toward the Atlantic, in a single long, crooked limb, the present conventional world slips away, allowing you to rethink, reinvent and get away with all manner of things. Maybe a sort of pre-modern living — with so few amenities and creature comforts — drew the urban cliques who gravitated there, repelled as many were by the excesses of capitalism.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Megan Specia
title: Here are the contenders to become the next prime minister.
description: A small group is stepping to center stage as Britain’s political crisis intensifies, including the rival Boris Johnson beat last time.
content: With Boris Johnson poised to step down as the leader of the Conservative Party, the spotlight is on who might succeed him as prime minister.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jesus Jiménez
title: Dallas Cowboys Face Criticism After Partnership With Black Rifle Coffee
description: The announcement drew criticism in part for its timing, a day after the deadly mass shooting in Highland Park, Ill.
content: The Dallas Cowboys are facing criticism after announcing a new partnership with Black Rifle Coffee, the veteran-owned brand popular with conservatives and gun owners that sells roasts with names like “AK Espresso,” “Murdered Out” and “Silencer Smooth.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sabrina Tavernise, Rachel Quester, Asthaa Chaturvedi, Jessica Cheung, Stella Tan, Lisa Chow, Liz O. Baylen, Marion Lozano, Dan Powell, Elisheba Ittoop and Chris Wood
title: An Anti-Abortion Campaigner on the Movement’s Historic Win
description: James Bopp, chief lawyer for the National Right to Life Committee, says that overturning Roe v. Wade is only the halfway point.
content: After Roe v. Wade was decided in 1973, a group of conservative lawyers embarked on what would become a decades-long mission to reverse the ruling.
source.name: The New York Times

title: What’s Next for Jack Harlow?
description: He’s one of hip-hop’s biggest emerging stars, and he’s cutting a very different path than the white rappers who came before him.
content: The rise of Jack Harlow has been one of hip-hop’s most curious narratives over the past two years. So far in 2022 he’s had a huge pop hit, “First Class,” and released his second major label album, “Come Home the Kids Miss You,” which debuted at No. 3. He is one of hip-hop’s biggest emerging stars, and one whose aims are purely centrist.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Roxane Gay
title: You Don’t Get Office Birthday Cake Over Zoom, Sorry
description: Missing a celebration may feel awkward. But leave the boss out of it.
content: Send questions about the office, money, careers and work-life balance to workfriend@nytimes.com. Include your name and location, or a request to remain anonymous. Letters may be edited.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Brad Plumer and Alisha Jucevic
title: Quitting Oil Income Is Hard, Even for States That Want Climate Action
description: Dozens of state and local budgets depend heavily on tax revenue from oil, gas and coal to fund schools, hospitals and more. Replacing that money is turning out to be a major challenge in the fight against climate change.
content: TAFT, Calif. — Every five years, this city of 7,000 hosts a rollicking, Old West-themed festival known as Oildorado. High schoolers decorate parade floats with derricks and pump jacks. Young women vie for the crown in a “Maids of Petroleum” beauty pageant. It’s a celebration of an industry that has sustained the local economy for the past century.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matt Wolf
title: On the London Stage, Families in Disarray
description: Two new plays, “The Southbury Child” and “Mad House,” explore domestic discord with contrasting degrees of success.
content: LONDON — Families are having a hard time on the London stage of late, and in one instance, at least, balloons are partly to blame. That’s the unusual starting point of “The Southbury Child,” a lively if uneven new play from Stephen Beresford that has arrived at the Bridge Theater (through Aug. 27) after its premiere south of London last month at the Chichester Festival Theater.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Anne Barnard
title: What the Gateway Deal Means for New Yorkers
description: A Times reporter breaks down how the long-stalled Hudson River train tunnel project could help the city, and why it might now actually happen.
content: Good morning. It’s Thursday. Today we’ll look at the nuts and bolts of the Hudson River tunnel project that just cleared a major hurdle, and why it’s so important to New York, New Jersey and even the country. And we’ll dig into the money and transparency problems the city comptroller just revealed in New York’s ferry system.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Neal E. Boudette
title: Mike Grier, the N.H.L.’s First Black General Manager, Started as a College Benchwarmer
description: Grier worked from being a reserve at Boston University to an N.H.L. mainstay. Now the league’s first Black general manager hopes to rebuild the Sharks and “open some doors for someone to follow.”
content: Mike Grier spent the first game of his freshman season at Boston University not on the ice but in the stands, unready for the lineup, minding a high school recruit checking out the program. He saw little ice time in the next three games and then was told that was what he could expect for the rest of the season, too.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Callie Holtermann and Katherine Schulten
title: A Year of Language Play: Our Vocabulary Challenges and How You Can Use Them
description: We invited students to invent new words and investigate old ones, tell stories, make videos, draw pictures and take quizzes.
content: The Learning Network has been through many iterations in its 23-year history, but there’s one feature that has always been part of our offerings: our Word of the Day.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Max Lakin
title: The Enduring Appeal of the Self-Taught Artist
description: For centuries, those who eschewed formal training have been either marginalized or obsessed over. Why are we so enthralled by people who create on their own terms?
content: ART SCHOOL, AT least as it exists in the U.S., is a relatively new invention. The availability of a degree in fine arts, and the expectation that an artist earn one, became typical around the end of World War II, when the G.I. Bill afforded veterans the ability to attend colleges and universities. Before then, aspirants to the art world largely figured out the mechanics themselves, through apprenticeships, maybe, or informal classes at independent schools like the Art Students League of New York, where working artists like the painter Thomas Hart Benton instructed Jackson Pollock, even if the instruction shaded toward the antagonistic (Benton despised abstraction; Pollock said the only thing that he learned from the older artist was how to drink a fifth of whiskey a day).
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matthew Mpoke Bigg
title: ‘This is Ukraine!’ The national flag is raised on Snake Island, officials say, in a symbol of Kyiv’s defiance of Moscow.
description: Ukraine has raised its blue and yellow national flag over Snake Island, the authorities said on Thursday, signaling the reconquest of a scrap of land in the Black Sea that has become a symbol of the country’s resistance to Russia’s invasion.

title: First, the Fish Fell From the Sky. Then They Washed Ashore.
description: In the past month, dead anchovies have been spotted on the streets of San Francisco. Last week, thousands appeared at the edge of a lagoon about 30 miles north.

title: ‘Fair Play’ Review: Casting a Floodlight on Invisible Labor
description: This documentary, a lucid look at household tasks based on Eve Rodsky’s best seller, pairs actionable guidance with testimony from real families.
content: The advice included within Eve Rodsky’s book “Fair Play,” a guide to sharing domestic labor and achieving harmony in the home, won’t blow your mind. A woman’s time is as valuable as a man’s? Who knew! But there is a fortifying effect to arranging these axioms in sequence.

author: By Valeriya Safronova
title: How Many Children Does Elon Musk Have?
description: Name-change documents filed in Texas show that the outspoken entrepreneur recently fathered twins with Shivon Zilis, a director at one of his companies.
content: Elon Musk, the billionaire Tesla founder, had twins in November with Shivon Zilis, a director at one of his companies, according to court documents made public on Wednesday. Neither Mr. Musk nor Ms. Zilis has spoken publicly about their children.

author: By Gregory Schmidt
title: Renters Face Fiercest Competition in Florida and the Northeast
description: Demand for apartments in Florida has intensified, followed by markets in Pennsylvania and New Jersey, as Americans embrace remote work.
content: As pandemic restrictions ease and remote work becomes a permanent fixture, Americans continue to seek homes in communities with more relaxed lifestyles — particularly in Florida and the Northeast, home to the country’s most competitive markets for renters, according to a new analysis of real estate data.

author: By Daniel Naroditsky
title: Chess Replay: You Versus Alekhine
description: Take on Alexander Alekhine in a recreation of a 13th World Championship game in The Hague, 1929.
content: This is Chess Replay, an interactive puzzle based on a historic chess game. As a solver, you embody a famous player during a critical game in his or her career. A new edition of this puzzle is published each week on Thursdays.

author: By Clyde Haberman
title: James Caan, Actor Who Won Fame in ‘The Godfather,’ Dies at 82
description: A Bronx native, he starred in countless movies and TV shows, but was most closely identified with the volatile character Sonny Corleone.
content: James Caan, who built a durable film career in varied roles across six decades but was forever identified most closely with one of his earliest characters, the quick-tempered, skirt-chasing Sonny Corleone in the original “Godfather” movie, died on Wednesday. He was 82.

author: By The New York Times
title: Show Us Where You’re Seeing Inflation
description: Our economics reporter wants to hear about what goods and services are getting more expensive.
content: With inflation at a 40-year high in the United States, our reporters want to know: What goods and services are getting more expensive for you in a way that has made you stop and take note? We’re interested in specifics: Are prices up for cereal? Exterminators? Paper towels? Haircuts? Shoes? Is there one item in particular whose cost has jumped more than you expected, or that particularly shapes your perception of how fast inflation is right now?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeanna Smialek
title: More Fed officials back a big July rate move, but downplay recession fears.
description: A central bank governor and president spoke in favor of a 0.75 percentage point rate increase this month, even as recession worries abound.
content: Two Federal Reserve officials expressed support on Thursday for making a second large rate increase at the central bank’s upcoming meeting and argued that, while there are early signs that the economy is slowing somewhat, data on gross domestic product overstate the extent of any pullback.

title: Start-Up Funding Falls the Most It Has Since 2019

title: Harvey Dinnerstein, Proudly Realistic Painter, Is Dead at 94
description: He documented the early days of the civil rights movement in evocative drawings. Later, his paintings examined details of the everyday life around him.
content: The Montgomery bus boycott was in its early days when Harvey Dinnerstein and his friend Burt Silverman — two socially conscious Realist painters motivated by the lack of photographic evidence of the protests — took the train from Penn Station in Manhattan to Alabama in 1956 to draw that seminal chapter in the nascent civil rights movement.

author: By Winston Choi-Schagrin
title: A Whale Feeding Frenzy in Antarctica Signals a Conservation Success
description: Once hunted to the brink of extinction, fin whales in the Southern Ocean have rebounded and returned to their historic feeding grounds, according to a new survey.
content: From a distance, it looked like thick fog across the horizon. But as the ship drew closer, the ocean bubbled as 150 fin whales, the planet’s second-largest creatures, dived and lunged against the water’s surface.
source.name: The New York Times

Comey, the former F.B.I. director, and his deputy, Andrew G. McCabe — both perceived enemies of former President Donald J. Trump — came to be faced with rare, exhaustive audits that the agency says are supposed to be random.

description: Best known for fantastical thrillers that doubled as political allegories, he also wrote hundreds of martial arts films for Bruce Lee and others.

author: By Mark Landler
title: For Boris Johnson, a Tumultuous Tenure Ends With a Messy Exit
description: The risk-taking bravado of Britain’s colorful prime minister was not enough to compensate for his shortcomings, or overcome a catastrophic loss of party support.

content: Last September, as cultural organizations began their fall seasons in a state of crisis, unsure if audiences would venture from their homes in the midst of a pandemic, Yuval Sharon, the artistic director of the Michigan Opera Theater, decided to mount a show called “Bliss.” A restaging of a marathon piece by the Icelandic performance artist Ragnar Kjartansson, “Bliss” requires its performers to replay the final three minutes of Mozart’s “The Marriage of Figaro” without pause for 12 hours.

author: By Casandra López and Victoria Chang
title: Poem: Sister Song
description: A longing for and memory of a murdered brother
content: The ghazal is a formal poem that has roots in seventh-century Arabia and was often sung by musicians. The poet Agha Shahid Ali introduced the form to America. “Ghazal” literally means “the cry of a gazelle” as it is being chased and about to die. Like many formal poems such as the sonnet, the ghazal, with its restrictions, can paradoxically illuminate and parse difficult emotions. In López’s poem, the emotion is grief — a longing for and memory of a murdered brother. This poem mostly follows the parameters of a ghazal with its repeated end word, “song,” and the inside rhyme of “forever,” “far,” “marred,” etc., as well as the poet’s name or reference to the poet (“Sister”) in the final line. One way this poem breaks the rules is that each couplet doesn’t stand alone as if it were its own poem. Instead, the end of the couplets often bleed into the next stanza, linking the narratives. Selected by Victoria Chang
source.name: The New York Times

author: By J. D. Biersdorfer
title: Here’s to Your Health
description: In “Doctors and Distillers,” Camper English explores the long-running interconnection between medicine and alcohol in daily life.
content: We have many reasons to be thankful for a nice gin and tonic, but as a malaria-busting beverage, it’s also proved more effective than a previously prescribed cocktail of brandy mixed with animal blood and pepper.  As Camper English explains in “Doctors and Distillers,” it did take a few centuries of scientific experimentation to move past those medieval apothecaries. Colonizing observers had to copy the Indigenous peoples’ use of South American cinchona tree bark (which contains the alkaloid quinine),  before someone got the notion to mix quinine with carbonated mineral water  — along with the juniper-infused gin spirit that had its own medicinal history around Europe.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eduardo Medina
title: Alaska Kills 4 Bears That Entered Homeless Camp
description: The bears had been rummaging through tents at a park managed by the city of Anchorage. No one was injured, according to a city spokesman.
content: Four black bears that had repeatedly entered a campground for homeless people in Anchorage, Alaska, and rummaged through tents in search of leftover food and trash were killed on Tuesday because the authorities said they posed “a risk to human safety.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Martha Gill
title: Boris Johnson Made a Terrible Mistake: He Apologized
description: The prime minister’s contrition opened the floodgates.

My husband loves the sticker, and I believe a lot of his enjoyment comes from my hating it so much. Can you please order him to remove it?

author: By Henry Fountain
title: Europe is heating up faster than other ‘hot spots,’ a study finds.
description: A new study confirmed that European heat events are increasing in frequency and cumulative intensity over the last four decades.
content: Western Europeans have experienced more than their share of heat waves in recent years, with frequent periods of blisteringly hot and potentially lethal weather almost every summer. This year, parts of the region suffered through intense heat even before summer began.

author: By Natasha Frost
title: Your Thursday Briefing
description: Boris Johnson’s crumbling support.
content: Boris Johnson, the British prime minister, has resisted calls to resign, even as a delegation of cabinet members yesterday went to Downing Street to plead with him to step down. More than 30 government ministers and aides have so far quit — yet Johnson has vowed to fight on, insisting he has a mandate from voters to steer Britain into its post-Brexit future.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alisha Haridasani Gupta and Logan Lynette for The New York Times
title: The Mental Health Benefits of an Inclusive Outdoor Escape
description: Amid pandemic stress and racial violence, many communities of color have turned to wilderness areas for healing.
content: For Cynthia Philips, it was the sound of bees, willows, crickets and the hum of a metallic Tibetan bowl that helped her overcome some of her anxieties.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tanya Sichynsky
title: Eating Well in the Great Outdoors
description: Cold noodle salads, recipes for camping vegans and cooking out of a cooler.

title: ‘This Much I Know to Be True’ Review: Nick Cave Prepares for the Stage
description: A new music documentary by Andrew Dominik explores the collaboration of Cave and Warren Ellis.
content: The singer-songwriter (and novelist and screenwriter) Nick Cave is a longtime chronicler of dread, erotic obsession, morality and mortality. The director Andrew Dominik, not exactly a screwball comedy guy himself (“Killing Them Softly”), proved an apt collaborator with Cave on the 2016 documentary “One More Time With Feeling.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Arthur Lubow
title: Donna Ferrato’s Camera Is a Weapon for Women
description: Best known for unmasking domestic violence, the pathbreaking photojournalist has a show timed to coincide with the reversal of Roe v. Wade.
content: Even with blackened eyes, the women in Donna Ferrato’s photographs look defiant, not defeated. A photojournalist and feminist activist who is best known for her documentation of domestic violence, Ferrato, 73, has also depicted women pursuing sexual pleasure, giving birth, raising children, enticing men and demonstrating in the streets. Her subject is women taking control of their bodies, and in her fiercely empathetic mission, sometimes she turns the camera on herself.

author: By Saif Hasnat and Karan Deep Singh
title: Bangladesh Sees Jump in Covid Cases Before Eid Celebrations
description: The average number of new cases has risen to the highest since February, signaling a new wave. The country’s health system nearly collapsed in August.
content: DHAKA, Bangladesh — Rebeka Beshra should be on a packed bus for the 150-mile journey to her parents’ home to celebrate Eid al-Adha, one of the biggest Muslim holidays.

author: By ‘First Person'
title: In Russia, Gay People Are Routinely Targeted. That’s Why This Ukrainian Soldier Is Fighting.
description: When Putin invaded, Oleksandr Zhuhan chose to defend a country that hasn’t always defended him.
content: Since the beginning of the war, Ukrainians of all backgrounds have come together to fight their common enemy, Russia. But for some Ukrainians, that enemy holds particular terror. In Russia, gay people are routinely targeted for their identity — arrested without cause and even tortured. That’s what motivated Oleksandr Zhuhan to join the volunteer Territorial Defense Forces, despite experiencing homophobia in Ukraine.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eshe Nelson

content: On a humid weekday evening last month, as shade began to slant across Central Park, a small crowd made a dance floor out of the Bethesda Fountain’s brick terrace. Disco rhythms pulsed from a DJ booth on one side of the plaza, crowned by a pink-tinted mirrorball. There were moments of voguing and house dancing, and a few children wiggling joyfully. But most in the group paired off, in every combination of genders, to do the hustle.

content: Every so often in “Thor: Love and Thunder,” the 92nd Marvel movie to hit theaters this year (OK, the third), the studio machinery hits pause, and the picture opens a portal to another dimension: Its star, Chris Hemsworth, embraces wholesale self-parody, a pair of giant screaming goats gallop along a rainbow highway and Russell Crowe flounces around in a flirty skirt and Shirley Temple curls. author: By Amanda Fortini
title: Why Are We Still Talking About Black Mountain College?
description: In 1933, a handful of renegade teachers opened a school in rural North Carolina that would go on to shape American art and art education for decades to come.
content: Among the most enduring and evocative images of Black Mountain College — the experimental liberal arts school in rural North Carolina that was founded during the depths of the Great Depression, and that fostered the talents of numerous artists during the uniquely hopeful and propulsive period that followed World War II — are several photographs of R. Buckminster (Bucky) Fuller, the eccentric inventor and designer, attempting to construct his first large-scale geodesic dome. It was the summer of 1948, and Fuller, who was a faculty member in residence at the school — along with the likes of Willem and Elaine de Kooning, John Cage, Merce Cunningham, Peter Grippe, Beaumont Newhall and Richard Lippold — had brought with him rolls of aluminum Venetian-blind scrap stock and enlisted students and faculty to help him build.

Some came clutching their parents’ hands; others raced ahead to greet old friends. But it wasn’t long before the 13-year-old happily joined an ice-breaking game. “Hi, my name is Anna,” she chanted, as she clapped out a rhythm that the others repeated back to her: “Ba-BAH-ba-ba-BAH.”

author: By Jay Caspian Kang
title: The Nihilism of the Minions

content: One of the peculiarities of the collective American memory is that we imagine that moral rigidity steadily declines over time. One generation, through experimentation and immense tolerance, disentangles the hang-ups of their parents, just as their children will ultimately do for them. This, of course, is nonsense. What’s particularly odd to me is that most of us are fully aware — at least on an intellectual level — that cultural moralizing ebbs and flows and there is no clear linearity to any of it. But we hold on to the idea that society got “freer” during our generation (whatever that means) because we want our own youthful indiscretions to have “pushed boundaries” (another useless phrase) and “changed the scope of what was possible” (ditto). And while we can usually imagine our own children will take that “freedom” even further, our narcissism forces us to worry that society will crumble as a result. We, in other words, believe we, and only we, have found the perfect level of moral decline.

title: It’s Time to Stop Living the American Scam

content: Ten years ago, I wrote an essay called “The Busy Trap,” about the curse of “busyness” that seemed endemic at the time. The treadmill had been imperceptibly increasing its speed for a while, and people were nervously starting to notice. As happens with a lot of unavoidable evils, they tried to rebrand their frantic busyness as a virtue. “Busy — so busy, crazy busy,” was the answer you got whenever you asked how they were. I came out, in my essay, as anti-busy; I advocated idling, daydreaming, hanging out and goofing off. My conclusion: “Life is too short to be busy.”

A raucous, enthralling exhibition of the great American painter Robert Colescott (1925-2009) has arrived at the New Museum, to revel in and dissect. “Art and Race Matters: The Career of Robert Colescott” is the first museum exhibition of this artist’s relentlessly provocative work to be seen in Manhattan since a 1989 show (also at the New Museum) and the most complete yet.
